summary.seg:
Produced at some point during the middle decades of the nineteenth century, this Book of Hours was made by the miniaturist Caleb Wing (b. 1801, d. 1875) Wing, C. W. (Charles William), active 1826-1860 (for whom, see: Backhouse, 'A Victorian connoisseur' (1968). It remains the only complete manuscript attributed to him; better known is Wing's restoration work, touching up or replacing damaged miniatures, for example, or his production of standalone sets of illuminations, some of which were traded on the open market as genuine illuminations. As Stella Panayotova has observed, 'Given the time and expense invested, [this manuscript] was probably created a modern replica for a wealthy patron rather than a forgery for the open market' (see Panayotova, (2016), p. 168). It was as a Book of Hours 'from the time of Francis I', however, that
Samuel Sandars Sandars, S. (Samuel) purchased this manuscript for £66 in 1892 - and upon the accession of Sandars' bequest at Cambridge University Library, it was dated to c. 1520. It is only through subsequent scholarship that the true history of this manuscript has become apparent.

Wing took inspiration for this Book of Hours from the Chasteauneuf Hours (now Paris, Bibliothèque nationale, MS nouv. acq. lat. 3210). While his miniatures in MS Add. 4126 were faithful recreations of those found there, Wing introduced significant changes that suggests his use of other sources: the text was copied in a Humanistic minuscule (as opposed to the textualis script in the Chasteauneuf Hours), the contents are different, as are the border motifs, layout and proportions of the text and images.

The Chasteauneuf Hours had been damaged by a flood in 1846 while in the possession of the London art dealer John Boykett Jarman (1782-1864) Jarman, John Boykett, 1782-1864 . Wing was employed by Jarman to restore some of his damaged manuscripts and it must have been after this that he undertook the production of a replica. Jarman's collection was sold in 1864; this manuscript is not among the items listed here or elsewhere as belonging to Jarman, so it seems either he disposed of it elsewhere or Wing made it for another patron. This probable date-range for the manuscript's production has been reinforced by the results of cutting-edge research undertaken at the Fitzwilliam Museum. Non-invasive analyses of the pigments through reflectance spectroscopy has indicated the presence of synthetic ultramarine, first produced in France around 1830, and the absence of pigments that became available commercially during the second half of the nineteenth century.
The manuscript went on display in the exhibition Colour: The art and science of illuminated manuscripts at the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge from 30 July-30 December 2016.

Dr James Freeman
Medieval Manuscripts Specialist
Cambridge University Library

msItem.title: Calendar
msItem.note:
Use of Paris. Entries in red include the following (as originally written):
Jan. 3: Genovefae
July 28: Annae ma.
Oct. 9: Dionysii
Nov. 3: Marcel ep.
Nov. 25: Cathari. vir.

list.item: John 1:1-14 with antiphon 'Te invocamus...', versicle, response and collect (f. 14r) 'Protector in te sperantium' (Bruylants II, 911)
John 18 and 19 with antiphon 'Adoramus te Christe...', versicle, response and collect (f. 23v-24r) 'Deus qui manus tuas et pedes tuas'.

msItem.title: Hours of the Blessed Virgin Mary
msItem.rubric: 24r Sequuntur hore beate virginis Marie secundum usum Romanum

msItem.title: Hours of the Holy Cross
msItem.rubric: 73r Sequuntur hore sancte crucis Ad matutinas
msItem.explicit: 76r Sis mihi solatium in mortis agone. Amen.

msItem.title: Hours of the Holy Spirit
msItem.rubric: 76v Sequuntur hore de sancto spiritu Ad matutinas
msItem.explicit: 79r Ut viumaus iugiter celi regione. Amen.

msItem.title: Penitential Psalms
msItem.incipit: 79v Domine ne in furore tuo arguas me
msItem.explicit: 87v Parce domine parce populo tuo quem redemisti precioso sanguine tuo ne in eternum irascaris nobis.

msItem.title: Litany of Saints
msItem.explicit: 79r Per eum qui venturus est iudicare viuos et mortuous et seculum per ignem. Amen.
msItem.note: Follows the preceding sections with a heading. The martyrs end with Denis, the confessors with Louis and Bonaventura. Francis (in capitals) appears together with Amand among the monks and hermits. Petronilla, Clare and Rosa appear among the virgins.

msItem.title: Office of the Dead
msItem.explicit: 119r Versus. Requiescant in pace. Responsorium. Amen. Finis

msItem.title: Suffrages for the Trinity, Father, Son and Holy Spirit
Suffrage for the Trinity
msItem.note: Collect beginning 'Omnipotens sempiterne deus qui dedisti famulis tuis...'

msItem.title: Suffrage for the Father
msItem.incipit: 119v: Mater (sic) de celis miserere nobis. Domine sancte pater omnipotens eterne deus qui coequalem

msItem.title: Suffrage for the Son
msItem.incipit: 120r: Fili redemptor mundi deus, Miserere nobis. Domine Iesu Christe fili dei vivi qui es verus et omnipotens deus

msItem.title: Suffrage for the Holy Spirit
msItem.incipit: 120v: Ad spiritum sanctum oratio. Spiritus sancte deus miserere nobis. Domine spiritus sancte deus, qui coequalis consubstantialis et coeternus

msItem.title: Prayer to the Virgin Mary
msItem.rubric: Oratio deuotissima ad honorem intemerate dei genitricis Marie
msItem.explicit: 123r Audi et exaudi me dulcissima virgo maria mater dei & misericordie. Amen.

msItem.title: Stabat Mater
msItem.rubric: 123r Deuota contemplatio beate marie iuxta crucem filii sui lachrymantis & ad compassionem eius saluatoris singulos inuitantis
msItem.incipit: 123r Stabat mater dolorosa iuxta crucem lachrymosa
msItem.explicit: 124r Quando corpus morietur fac vt anime donetur paradisi gloria, Amen.
msItem.note: Followed (fols 124r-v) by a verse, response and prayer: 'Versus: Tuam ipsius animam doloris gladius pertransibit. Responsorium: Vt reuelentur ex multis cordibus cogitationes. Oratio: Interueniat pro nobis quesumus domine...Qui viuis & regnas deus, per omnia secula seculorum Amen'.

msItem.title: Two prayers to be said on the Sabbath in honour of the Virgin Mary
msItem.rubric: 124v Oratio deuota dicenda diebus sabbati ad honorem intemerate dei genitricis Marie
msItem.incipit: 124v Missus est gabriel Angelus ad Mariam virginem desponsatam Ioseph
msItem.explicit: 128r qui deus & homo ventururus est iudicare viuos & mortuos & seculum per ignem, Amen
msItem.incipit: 128r Te deprecor ergo mitissimam piissimam misericordissimam castissimam speciosissimam dei genitricem mariam
msItem.explicit: 128r Qui cum patre & spiritu sancto viuit & regnat deus, per omnia secula seculorum, Amen.

msItem.title: Memoriae
msItem.explicit: 137r gloriam consequamur in celis. Per dominum nostrum.
msItem.note:
Twenty-three memoriae, each with versicle, response and collect. The subjects are (with references for the collects and antiphons):
Michael: Bruylants II 387
John the Baptist: Bruylants II 856
John the Evangelist: Bruylants II 520
Peter and Paul: Bruylants II 212
All Apostles: Bruylants II 140
Stephen: Bruylants II 797
Laurence: Bruylants II 178
Sebastian: cf. Leroquais LH II, 49 (ending differs)
All Saints: Bruylants II 403
Nicholas: Bruylants II 299
Claude
Francis: antiphon, RH 40727; collect Bruylants II 331
Louis: Bruylants II 296
Martin: Bruylants II 433
Invention of the Cross: Bruylants II 368
Anthony: antiphon, cf. RH 1203; collect, cf. Hor. Ebor. 133
Anne: antiphon, RH 24692; collect, Speculum Spiritualium, f. ccvi verso. Cf. Leroquais LH II 207, also Lyell Cat. p. 374
Mary Magdalene: collect, cf. F.H. Dickinson, Missale ad Usum...Sarum (Bruntisland, 1861-83), col. 817
Catherine: antiphon, RH 34646; collect, Bruylants II 322
Barbara: antiphon, RH 6711; for the whole memoria, cf. Hoskins no. 7
Genevieve: RH 30425
All Saints (bis)
Blaise: RH 2056; for the whole memoria, cf. Hoskins no. 86

listBibl.bibl: Bruylants II 387, 856, 520, 212, 797, 178; Leroquais LH II, 49 (ending differs); Bruylants II 403, 299;

msItem.title: Prayer to the Virgin Mary, in French
msItem.rubric: 137r Deuote oraison a la vierge Marie a dire par chacun iour A ffin que a la mort l'ennemy ne puysse nuyre a l'ame

msItem.title: Prayer to guardian angel
msItem.incipit: 137v Ange de dieu qui mas en garde
msItem.explicit: 137v En la gloire du Roy Iesus. Amen.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

collation.p:
The manuscript comprises nineteen quires, mainly of 8 leaves, as follows:
Quires 1-26 (ff. 1-12)
Quires 3-138 (ff. 13-92)
Quire 146 (ff. 93-98)
Quires 15-198(ff. 99-138)

layout.seg: Ruled in red ink, frame and line. Single column, 20 lines (16 in the calendar). Written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in humanistic script by a single scribe.

decoNote.p: Sixteen half-page miniatures, surrounded by gold-framed borders, each with a bas-de-page panel containing jewels, cameos, natural flowers, etc. on grounds of gold or of blue dotted with gold. The figures in the miniatures are usually of half-length.

list.item: 13r St John on Patmos (Sequences of the Gospels); in the foreground, a young man and his wife kneel in prayer (presumably the original owners of the manuscript on which this replica is based)
79v: David and attendant watch Bethsheba from a loggia (Penitential Psalms)
94v: Woman flees from Death, who is wearing a shroud and wielding an arrow, and is catching her by the skirt (Office of the Dead)
132v: St Francis with stigmata; in the foreground, apparently the same young couple kneel in prayer (Memoriae)

decoNote.p: Two small miniatures in gold frames, positioned within the text block.
In Quire 6 (37r-44v), each page is framed in a design of gold cords or branchwork, outlined in blue or green.
Two- to three-line initials in gold or colours on contrasting coloured or gold ground, incorporating fine filigree infill, vines, flowers or fruit.
One-line initials in gold or colours on contrasting coloured or gold ground, incorporating filigree infill.
Line-fillers formed of patterned strips or stylised twigs is gold, blue, green and red.

binding.p: Gold-tooled olive morocco over wooden boards, with metal corner and centre pieces, gilt edges, and a red silk lining (19th century).

origin.p: The manuscript has been identified as the work of the miniaturist Caleb Wing (b. 1801, d. 1875) Wing, C. W. (Charles William), active 1826-1860 , who also worked on CUL MS Add. 4109.

provenance.p: Edward Henry Lawrence, F.S.A. Lawrence, Edward Henry, F.S.A. : his sale, Sotheby's, London, 9 May 1892, lot 307 ([ii] recto).
Purchased by Quaritch on commission for Samuel Sandars (b. 1837, d. 1894) Sandars, S. (Samuel) for £66 ([ii] recto).

acquisition.p: Bequeathed to Cambridge University Library by Sandars Sandars, S. (Samuel) in 1894 (his bookplate, with number 'SSS. 37. 1', f. [i] recto).

recordHist.source: This record draws on an extended unpublished description of the manuscript by Jayne Ringrose, which was published in summary form in Summary Catalogue of the Additional Medieval Manuscripts in Cambridge University Library acquired before 1940 (Woodbridge, 2009), used here by kind permission of the Boydell Press, and an unpublished description of the manuscript by H.L. Pink (now UA ULIB 7/3/75).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.
